articles.headline: Senate Leaders Agree on 2-Month Extension of Payroll Tax Cut
articles.snippet: The 112th Congress lurched toward the end of its tumultuous first session Friday as the House passed a $1 trillion spending bill and sent it to the Senate for approval.
articles.abstract: The 112th Congress lurched toward the end of its tumultuous first session Friday as the House passed a $1 trillion spending bill and sent it to the Senate for approval.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate leaders said on Friday night that they had reached a deal that would extend a payroll tax cut for two months — falling far short of the yearlong extension they had been seeking. The agreement would also speed the decision process for the construction of an oil pipeline from Canada to the Gulf Coast, a provision necessary to win over Republicans who opposed the tax break.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Robert Pear

articles.headline: A Boggle of BlackBerrys
articles.snippet: After Research in Motion announced a delay in its new BlackBerry line and an intention to focus on promoting its existing phones, stocks fell to an eight-year low.
articles.abstract: After Research in Motion announced a delay in its new BlackBerry line and an intention to focus on promoting its existing phones, stocks fell to an eight-year low.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Research in Motion’s chief executives, Mike Lazaridis and Jim Balsillie, frightened its investors Thursday when they said the company would not have new BlackBerry phones until late in 2012. Until then, they said, RIM would heavily promote the existing lineup.

articles.headline: Taking Fund-Raising To a New Level
articles.snippet: Research on your fund-raising habits is now commonly used by organizations trying to entice you to donate or to give more.
articles.abstract: Research on your fund-raising habits is now commonly used by organizations trying to entice you to donate or to give more.
articles.lead_paragraph: All of the nonprofit groups whose solicitations fill up your mailbox at this time of year badly want you to like them.

articles.headline: Despite Delay, the 100-Watt Bulb Is on Its Way Out
articles.snippet: A rider on an omnibus spending bill prohibits the Energy Department from enforcing new efficiency standards on light bulbs. But the industry is unlikely to change course now.
articles.abstract: A rider on an omnibus spending bill prohibits the Energy Department from enforcing new efficiency standards on light bulbs. But the industry is unlikely to change course now.
articles.lead_paragraph: The law to phase out traditional incandescent light bulbs was promoted as a simple, almost painless, change when Congress first passed it. By requiring that light bulbs use at least 25 percent less electricity, starting in 2012, the nation would use less energy, manufacturers would invent more efficient types of bulbs and the planet would be spared millions of tons of carbon emissions every year.

articles.headline: Amazon Says Long Term And Means It
articles.snippet: Amazon.com, under its chief, Jeff Bezos, follows a growth-oriented strategy that sometimes disappoints investors who want near-term profit.
articles.abstract: Amazon.com, under its chief, Jeff Bezos, follows a growth-oriented strategy that sometimes disappoints investors who want near-term profit.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 1997, the year Amazon.com went public, its chief executive, Jeff Bezos, issued a manifesto: “It’s all about the long term,” he said. He warned shareholders “we may make decisions and weigh tradeoffs differently than some companies” and urged them to make sure that a long-term approach “is consistent with your investment policy.” Amazon’s management and employees “are working to build something important, something that matters to our customers, something that we can tell our grandchildren about,” he added.

articles.headline: Millions From Diamonds Go to Mugabe, Observers Say
articles.snippet: Tens of millions of dollars in diamond profits are said to be bypassing the treasury of Zimbabwe and ending up with President Robert Mugabe and his supporters.
articles.abstract: Tens of millions of dollars in diamond profits are said to be bypassing the treasury of Zimbabwe and ending up with President Robert Mugabe and his supporters.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — Tens of millions of dollars in diamond profits — perhaps more — are being secretly extracted from state-owned mines in eastern Zimbabwe, bypassing the nation’s treasury and raising fears that President Robert Mugabe is amassing wealth to help extend his 31-year reign, according to monitoring groups, diplomats, lawmakers and analysts.

articles.headline: Investors Scrutinizing JPMorgan’s Mortgages
articles.snippet: Lawyers are examining $95 billion worth of mortgages that may have been put in JPMorgan Chase securities before the housing bubble burst.
articles.abstract: Lawyers are examining $95 billion worth of mortgages that may have been put in JPMorgan Chase securities before the housing bubble burst.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bank of America, the firm perhaps hardest hit by mortgage-related lawsuit woes, might have some company in the courthouse soon.

articles.headline: Paul’s ‘Ground Game,’ in Place Since ’08, Gives Him an Edge
articles.snippet: Ron Paul’s built-in networks of loyal backers from his 2008 presidential run have given him a decisive organizational advantage this election season.
articles.abstract: Ron Paul’s built-in networks of loyal backers from his 2008 presidential run have given him a decisive organizational advantage this election season.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANKENY, Iowa — It was four years ago that Ross Witt, a soft-spoken electrical engineer at John Deere, overcame his natural discomfort with knocking on hundreds of his neighbors’ doors during dinnertime as a precinct coordinator for Ron Paul’s campaign.

articles.headline: For Senate Tax Cut Stopgap, Odds in House Are Uncertain
articles.snippet: A two-month extension of the payroll-tax holiday — should it get through the House — adds to a series of 11th-hour Congressional deals that simply pushed the issues involved forward.
articles.abstract: A two-month extension of the payroll-tax holiday — should it get through the House — adds to a series of 11th-hour Congressional deals that simply pushed the issues involved forward.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Capping a year of last-minute, half-loaf legislation, the Senate voted overwhelmingly on Saturday to extend a payroll tax cut for only two months, with the chamber’s leaders and the White House proclaiming victory, even as they punted into the new year the issue of how to further extend the tax cut and unemployment benefits.

articles.headline: For Law Schools, a Price to Play the A.B.A.’s Way
articles.snippet: A law school in Tennessee reflects the problems many such schools face: meeting stringent, and costly, American Bar Association rules, while also trying to be affordable to students.
articles.abstract: A law school in Tennessee reflects the problems many such schools face: meeting stringent, and costly, American Bar Association rules, while also trying to be affordable to students.
articles.lead_paragraph: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.

articles.headline: In Strikes on Libya by NATO, an Unspoken Civilian Toll
articles.snippet: NATO airstrikes killed and wounded dozens of civilians in Libya, but the alliance has largely refused to investigate the casualties.
articles.abstract: NATO airstrikes killed and wounded dozens of civilians in Libya, but the alliance has largely refused to investigate the casualties.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — NATO’s seven-month air campaign in Libya, hailed by the alliance and many Libyans for blunting a lethal crackdown by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and helping to push him from power, came with an unrecognized toll: scores of civilian casualties the alliance has long refused to acknowledge or investigate.
articles.byline: By C. J. Chivers and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Slapped Wrists at WaMu
articles.snippet: The $64.7 million settlement between federal regulators and Washington Mutual is another example of the minimalist punishment meted out to players in the credit boom and bust.
articles.abstract: The $64.7 million settlement between federal regulators and Washington Mutual is another example of the minimalist punishment meted out to players in the credit boom and bust.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN Washington Mutual collapsed in 2008, it was the largest bank failure in American history. So the $64.7 million settlement struck last week by federal banking regulators and three former WaMu executives seems like small potatoes indeed.

articles.headline: Rules to Stop Pupil and Teacher From Getting Too Social Online
articles.snippet: School districts across the country are imposing strict new guidelines that ban private conversations between teachers and their students on cellphones and online platforms.
articles.abstract: School districts across the country are imposing strict new guidelines that ban private conversations between teachers and their students on cellphones and online platforms.
articles.lead_paragraph: Faced with scandals and complaints involving teachers who misuse social media, school districts across the country are imposing strict new guidelines that ban private conversations between teachers and their students on cellphones and online platforms like Facebook and Twitter.

articles.headline: As Wars End, Young Veterans Return to Scant Jobs
articles.snippet: Legions of veterans have a harder time finding work than other people their age, a situation officials say will worsen in coming years.
articles.abstract: Legions of veterans have a harder time finding work than other people their age, a situation officials say will worsen in coming years.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — In Afghanistan, Cpl. Clayton Rhoden earned about $2,500 a month jumping into helicopters to chase down improvised explosive devices or check out suspected bomb factories.

articles.headline: Economic Health in Iowa Conflicts With a G.O.P. Theme
articles.snippet: Iowa, which largely sidestepped the housing crash, is an odd staging ground for an election that is often said to be all about jobs and the economy.
articles.abstract: Iowa, which largely sidestepped the housing crash, is an odd staging ground for an election that is often said to be all about jobs and the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: PELLA, Iowa — Mitt Romney, Newt Gingrich, Rick Perry and nearly every other Republican presidential candidate has visited the same sprawling factory complex here in recent months. They came to talk about business and manufacturing and, of course, to hit hard on the dominant theme of the campaign trail: unemployment and the struggling economy.

articles.headline: A Partisan Lightning Rod Is Undeterred
articles.snippet: Intensifying heat on Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. comes as the Justice Department is stepping into some of the most politically divisive issues of the day.
articles.abstract: Intensifying heat on Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. comes as the Justice Department is stepping into some of the most politically divisive issues of the day.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — For nearly three years, Republicans have attacked Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on national security and civil rights issues. For months, they have criticized him over a gun-trafficking investigation gone awry, with dozens of leaders calling for his resignation. Last week, more than 75 members of Congress co-sponsored a House resolution expressing “no confidence” in his leadership.

articles.headline: Vaclav Havel, Former Czech President, Dies at 75
articles.snippet: Mr. Havel’s eloquent dissections of Communist rule helped to destroy it in revolutions that brought down the Berlin Wall and swept him into power.
articles.abstract: Mr. Havel’s eloquent dissections of Communist rule helped to destroy it in revolutions that brought down the Berlin Wall and swept him into power.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vaclav Havel, the Czech writer and dissident whose eloquent dissections of Communist rule helped to destroy it in revolutions that brought down the Berlin Wall and swept Mr. Havel himself into power, died on Sunday. He was 75.
articles.byline: By Dan Bilefsky and Jane Perlez

articles.headline: Extension of Tax Cut Stalls in House as G.O.P. Objects
articles.snippet: The House Republican leader’s rejection of a short-term, bipartisan Senate measure to extend a payroll tax break set the stage for a bitter year-end Congressional collision.
articles.abstract: The House Republican leader’s rejection of a short-term, bipartisan Senate measure to extend a payroll tax break set the stage for a bitter year-end Congressional collision.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House Republican leader on Sunday flatly rejected a short-term, bipartisan Senate measure to extend a payroll tax break and unemployment insurance, setting the stage for a bitter year-end Congressional collision and the potential loss of benefits for millions of Americans.

articles.headline: The Queen of Cable TV
articles.snippet: Bonnie Hammer, chairwoman of NBCUniversal Cable Entertainment, oversees networks and cable channels that contribute close to $2 billion in profits for the company.
articles.abstract: Bonnie Hammer, chairwoman of NBCUniversal Cable Entertainment, oversees networks and cable channels that contribute close to $2 billion in profits for the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: Early in Bonnie Hammer’s first stint running a cable network, she knew something was wrong. The SciFi channel was emerging as a destination for fans of the genre, largely on her strategy of reviving the mini-series.

articles.headline: Apple App Makers on Edge for Holidays
articles.snippet: On Thursday, Apple will stop accepting app submissions until after Christmas, and developers are scrambling to beat the deadline.
articles.abstract: On Thursday, Apple will stop accepting app submissions until after Christmas, and developers are scrambling to beat the deadline.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Christmas morning, millions of people will unwrap new iPads, iPhones and iPod Touches — and immediately start downloading games and other applications for them. It is the biggest day of the year for app sales, which can mean big money for developers.

articles.headline: A Comic Distributes Himself
articles.snippet: Louis C.K. sold his latest stand-up special on his Web site with no obligations to a studio, pointing a way forward for performers and their fans.
articles.abstract: Louis C.K. sold his latest stand-up special on his Web site with no obligations to a studio, pointing a way forward for performers and their fans.
articles.lead_paragraph: Louis C. K. is something of a pirate in the entertainment world, a man who has ignored propriety on his way to building a huge comic franchise. So it’s odd to see him put one of his shows for sale on the Web and politely ask fans not to rip him off.

articles.headline: Instability a New Fear for Investors in Russia
articles.snippet: Investors fear short-term instability, despite having common ground with protesters seeking political reforms.
articles.abstract: Investors fear short-term instability, despite having common ground with protesters seeking political reforms.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The street protests in Moscow that have raised the prospect of deep political reforms have had the opposite effect on the country’s stock exchange: it has plummeted faster than any other major equity market in the world over the last two weeks.

articles.headline: Channel’s Swift Rise Attracts Ads and Envy
articles.snippet: The History channel’s main attraction is reality television, and its success also attests to the success of documentary-style dramas and competitions featuring average people.
articles.abstract: The History channel’s main attraction is reality television, and its success also attests to the success of documentary-style dramas and competitions featuring average people.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last year, the History channel had a growth spurt, gaining hundreds of thousands of viewers while most of its competitors struggled to grow at all. This year, even more remarkably, the channel did it again.

articles.headline: Making a List, and Taking It to the Pawnshop
articles.snippet: The TV series “Pawn Stars” has drawn a more mainstream audience into the shops, but the search for prices even below those of the big-box retailers is bringing in more shoppers, too.
articles.abstract: The TV series “Pawn Stars” has drawn a more mainstream audience into the shops, but the search for prices even below those of the big-box retailers is bringing in more shoppers, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: Children in San Mateo, Calif., whispered their wish lists to Santa Claus this weekend at Best Collateral, a pawnshop in a strip mall about 20 miles south of San Francisco.
articles.byline: By Andrew Martin and Stephanie Clifford

articles.headline: Buyout Profits Keep Flowing to Romney
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney’s retirement deal with Bain Capital has been worth millions of dollars each year since 1999.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney’s retirement deal with Bain Capital has been worth millions of dollars each year since 1999.
articles.lead_paragraph: Almost 13 years ago, Mitt Romney left Bain Capital, the successful private equity firm he had helped start, and moved to Utah to rescue the Salt Lake City Olympic Games and begin a second career in public life.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore, Christopher Drew and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Kim Jong-il, North Korean Dictator, Dies
articles.snippet: Within hours of announcing Mr. Kim’s death, which had been kept secret for roughly two days, North Korea on Monday test-fired missiles off its eastern coast, a news report said.
articles.abstract: Within hours of announcing Mr. Kim’s death, which had been kept secret for roughly two days, North Korea on Monday test-fired missiles off its eastern coast, a news report said.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Kim Jong-il, the North Korean leader who realized his family’s dream of turning his starving, isolated country into a nuclear-weapons power even as it sank further into despotism, died on Saturday of a heart attack while traveling on his train, according to an announcement Monday by the country’s state-run media.
articles.byline: By Choe Sang-Hun and David E. Sanger
